property.name: text
property.value:
Simulate a ball dropping towards a rotating disc. The disc has a hole (or door) that will allow the ball to drop through if the disc is properly aligned (zero rotation) at the time of impact.
Ball drops are detected by a photosensor, which reports the time at which the ball was detected, as well as its initial velocity. The controller adjusts the speed of the disc to ensure the door is directly below the ball at the time of impact.
Following the initial ball drop (t=0), the next ball will drop after a small delay. Between ball drops, the disc should return to its default speed.
All units used in this model are SI (meters, seconds), except for rotation which is in units of encoder units, parameterized by encoderTicksPerRevolution.

property.name: text
property.value:
When triggered, generate two drop pulses that correspond to the physical times a ball passes through two photodetectors separated by a fixed distance.
Introduce a random delay between drop events, which will randomize the initial velocity of the ball in motion.

entity.name: Gaussian
entity.doc: Create a sequence of gaussian random variables

property.name: text
property.value:
Continuous rotating disc plant model. The motor is modeled as a simple inertial motor where input voltage is proportional to output torque. The LevelCrossingDetector generates a discrete output event when the motor encoder is incremented.
Feedback prevents the angle integrator from exceeding one encoder tick.

property.name: text
property.value:
When a ball drop is detected (an event is present on the dropPulse port), record the initial time and velocity of the ball and determine when the ball will impact the disc. These values are stored in registers and used as controller parameters.
When disc state changes, the servo encoder receives a tick event. These events are frequent and pseudo-periodic, and are the driving signal of the controller. If a ball is in the air, the Disc Control actor adjusts the servo control signal in order to align the disc door at the time of impact. If no ball is in the air, the Disc Control actor adjusts the disc rate to its default value.
It is important to note that the encoder signal directly sets the controller rate. If a high- precision controller is used (more ticks per rotation), or the default disc rate is high, then the controller will operate at a higher frequency.

property.name: text
property.value:
Convert the servo encoder signal into the disc rate and angle. Each tick event corresponds to a fractional degree of rotation; the time delay between these ticks is inversely proportional to the rate.
The value of the encoder tick reflects the number of ticks recorded for a single encoder event; this value should be 1, though values of 0 can force controller output without affecting disc state.
TODO: Accumulator needs to reset after reaching encoderTicksPerRevolution; this can be done with feedback, but significantly slows down simulation.

property.name: text
property.value:
Simple proportional-integral (PI) control for the disc.
This controller will respond to angle error events, in which case the angle at the time of impact is the control variable, and rate error events, in which case the rate of the disc is the control variable. The control variable not used will have its accumulator reset.
FIXME: Reset events should only be generated once...

property.name: text
property.value: Receive drop pulses; the time difference between the two events corresponds to the initial velocity of the ball in motion. The second event occurs when the ball in motion is a fixed altitude from the disc.

property.name: text
property.value:
Simple kinematics model for a dropping ball. Given initial altitude, initial velocity, and the time at which these values were valid (t0), calculate the final velocity and time of impact (with respect to global time).
impactTime = (sqrt(initialVelocity^2 + 2*g*initialAltitude) - initialVelocity) / g impactVelocity = initialVelocity + g*impactTime

property.name: text
property.value:
Prior to impact: output the projected angle of the disc at impact. The desired angle of the disc is zero degrees. Because angle is the variable we wish to control, no rate error is output.
After impact: we wish to control rate, which is fixed at a default rate. No angle error is output.

property.name: text
property.value: Return the physical time until impact, or zero if impact has occured.

property.name: text
property.value: Given the current disc state, determine the angle of the disc at the time of impact.
